event.summary: 07/27/1993: Three bombs exploded overnight in Milan and Rome. In this first incident a car bomb exploded in front of the Modern Art Museum Milan’s Gothic Cathedral. 5 died and 20 were wounded. The "Armed Phalange," claimed responsibility.
event.target1: The Modern Art Museum (Milan’s Gothic Cathedral)
event.motive: The perpetrators were demanding political reform in light of the nation's massive corruption scandal
event.weapdetail: A fire was set to a car in an effort to draw firefighters and police to the scene. The bomb explode soon after their arrival.
event.addnotes: Police discounted the "Armed Phalange" as a real force, pointing out that the organization, if it really exists, only calls in after terrorist acts have been reported by the media. This case was one of three related attacks (cf. 1993072702;1993072703).
event.scite1: Charles Ridley, “Car Bombs in Rome and Milan Kill Five, Wound at least 32,” United Press International, July 27, 1993.
event.scite2: “Mystery of Car Bombings Deepen,” Hobart Mercury, July, 30, 1993.
event.scite3: “Terror Bomb Blasts Kill Five, Wound 29, Agence France Presse, July 28, 1993.
